bestBHT.bht: Jesus warns against following uncharitable and unjust leaders, emphasizing the need for humility. Christians should not assume the role of a judgmental leader, just as their Master did not. Instead, they should strive to be humble, like Jesus. Addressing one's own faults before correcting others is essential, as depicted in the imagery of the blind leading the blind and the concept of the beam in one's eye. Through being taught by God, disciples can attain the fullness of their Master's stature.

Henry Alford: The parabolic saying, implying the unfitness of an uncharitable and unjustly condemning leader (the Lord was speaking primarily to His Apostles) to perform his office, leads to the assertion [ver. 40] that no Christian ought to assume in this respect an office of judging which his Master never assumed; but rather will every well-instructed Christian strive to be humble as his Master was.
Then follows the reproof of vv. 41–43; and vv. 44, 45 and 46–49 shew us, expanded in different images, what the beam in the eye is, to which our first efforts must be directed.

Can the blind lead the blind? See this in quite another connexion, Matt. xv. 14, where Peter answers, 'Declare unto us this parable'—meaning apparently the last uttered words, which the Lord however explains not specifically, but by entering into the whole matter.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: in the Sermon on the Mount, but recorded by Matthew in another and
Marvin Vincent: The word combines the ideas of leading and instructing.
Shall they not? Expecting an affirmative answer.
John Calvin: Luke relates this saying without mentioning any occurrence, but states generally, that Christ made use of this parable."
It is no doubt possible that Christ may have spoken this parable more than once.
I have not hesitated to insert here what Luke relates without fixing the time.
Philip Schaff: This indicates plainly that the connection with what precedes is broken off.
The close connection with what follows forbids the view that they are inserted here out of theft place.
Probably a familiar saying of our Lord.
Archibald T. Robertson: The blind leading the blind, the mote and the beam.
The use of μητ in the question shows that a negative answer is expected.
Ουχ, a sharpened negative from ουκ, in a question expecting the answer Yes.
John Gill: Can the blind lead the blind?...If they do, shall they not both fall into the ditch?"
They may do so, as the blind Scribes and Pharisees led the blind people of the Jews, which is what our Lord intends.
Yes, verily, what else can be expected?
John Wesley: Can the blind lead the blind?" - Can the scribes teach this way, which they know not themselves?
Will not they and their scholars perish together?" - Can they make their disciples any better than themselves?
But as for those who will be my disciples, they shall be all taught of God; who will enable them to come to the measure of the stature of the fulness of their Master.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 6:39, Jesus warns against the dangers of following blind leaders who are uncharitable and unjust in their judgments. He emphasizes that no Christian should assume the role of a judge, as this was not even assumed by the Master Himself. Instead, believers should strive to be humble, just as Jesus was. The subsequent reproofs in verses 41-43 highlight the importance of addressing our own faults before trying to correct others. The imagery of the blind leading the blind and the concept of the beam in one's eye illustrate the need for self-reflection and personal growth. By being taught by God, disciples can strive to reach the fullness of the stature of their Master.

Jesus cautions against following uncharitable and unjust leaders who unjustly condemn others, urging Christians not to assume the role of a judgmental leader. Instead, believers must strive to be humble, much like Jesus. The subsequent reproofs emphasize the importance of addressing one's own faults before correcting others. The imagery of the blind leading the blind and the concept of the beam in one's eye highlight the need for self-reflection and personal growth. By being taught by God, disciples can strive to reach the fullness of the stature of their Master.

Jesus warns against following blind leaders who unjustly condemn others, emphasizing the need for humility. Unfit to judge, Christians should focus on their own faults before correcting others. Through the imagery of the blind leading the blind, Jesus illustrates the consequences of following misguided leaders. The concept of the beam in one's eye highlights the importance of self-reflection. By being taught by God, disciples can aspire to reach the fullness of their Master's stature.

Jesus cautions against uncharitable and unjust leaders, urging Christians not to judge. Rather, they should embody humility like their Master. Addressing their own faults is crucial before attempting to correct others. The imagery of the blind leading the blind underscores the consequences of following misguided leaders. Through the concept of the beam in one's eye, Jesus emphasizes the need for self-reflection. By being taught by God, disciples can aspire to attain the fullness of their Master's stature.

Jesus warns against following uncharitable and unjust leaders, emphasizing the need for humility. Christians should not assume the role of a judgmental leader, just as their Master did not. Instead, they should strive to be humble, like Jesus. Addressing one's own faults before correcting others is essential, as depicted in the imagery of the blind leading the blind and the concept of the beam in one's eye. Through being taught by God, disciples can attain the fullness of their Master's stature.
